6.56.text:
Are you mad that I’m doing two Overwatch
videos in a row?

9.75.text: Well I don’t give a shit.

13.04.text:
Plus, I let you off easily last week by focusing
on something pedantic that, honestly, doesn’t

19.91.text:
Which, given by the steeper-than-usual like-to-dislike
ratio, annoyed more than its fair share of

33.80.text:
I’m writing to you today Blizzard because,
well.

38.15.text:
It’s finally time to talk about my least
favorite character: Roadhog.

43.20.text:
Now, I know, I know, you’re thinking to
yourself: Roadhog?

48.83.text: And, granted, Roadhog is no Mei.

50.73.text:
And there’s definitely a unique kind of
terror that you only feel as a support character

55.11.text:
when you round a corner and come face-to-face
with that little she-devil, you catch her

60.00.text:
eye, and she sprays you down while your body
slowly freezes to a stop while you struggle

65.97.text:
with futility to escape and she looks you
right in the eyes with that adorable little

71.33.text:
face with an evil little fucking smile as
she plasters the walls with your brains by

76.28.text: shoving an icicle through your temple.

78.46.text:
In fact, there are a few such situations of
hopelessness you learn to instinctively fear

84.68.text:
Whenever McCree tells you what time of the
day it is, whenever D.va laughs and says “nerf

88.95.text:
this” and you have NOwhere to run, whenever
you get pinned by fucking Reinhardt, or you

93.76.text:
hear Genji shout some bullshit in Japanese,
you know you’re going to have a bad fucking

102.28.text:
There’s nothing, nothing, NOTHING that compares
to when you see a Roadhog half a mile away

107.52.text: and he starts lumbering toward you.

111.30.text:
GET AWAY” and then his fucking, what is
that, a fucking rusty meat hook?

114.94.text:
Whatever the fuck it is, he hurls it approximately
5000 feet, through walls, and by god that

121.11.text:
damned hook will always fucking grab you and
rip you away from what you’re doing until

126.57.text:
you’re face-to-face with this giant meatmonster
of a man.

130.09.text:
And if he’s being played by any player worth
their salt, there’s a 95% chance he’s

134.70.text:
going to instantly kill you with a devastating
headshot and meathook to the face.

140.81.text:
It just--it stresses me the fuck out more
than anything.

142.96.text: And I swear his goddamn hook recharges instantly.

146.17.text:
There’s nothing that freaks me out more
than a Roadhog who has a raging hateboner

149.86.text:
for me as the healer and makes it their personal
mission to take me down.

153.51.text:
And while I do think that it’s bullshit
that the damned thing seems like it can travel

160.26.text: I’m not going to whine about him being broken.

164.43.text:
What happens between me and monitor is nobody’s
business but ours.

168.98.text:
Folk have been asking me to take a close look
at Roadhog for a while now, and since I meant

173.91.text:
to last week but got distracted by bullshit
that didn’t mean anything, I figure I owe

178.55.text: you a real topic on something awesome.

181.08.text:
SO: Roadhog’s signature technique is the
ability to throw a giant hook across a great

186.56.text:
distance, grab a motherfucker, and whip them
to himself fast-as-fuck like a fat Scorpion

193.44.text:
Also why the fuck is Kombat spelled with a
K?

198.70.text:
Is this some 1990s bullshit idea of how to
be edgy, like, when everbody was spelling

209.58.text: There’s no character he can’t yank away.

213.49.text:
I mean, how strong do you have to be in order
to one-arm a fucking Mech across a vast distance?

218.86.text: Let’s figure this the fuck out!

225.71.text:
But we have no idea what Bastion or D.va are
made out of.

230.58.text:
Mech suits don’t really exist to compare
to, nor do, what is Bastion?

237.36.text:
Since there’s no mass or weight recorded
anywhere for these characters, the best we

240.57.text: could do is a big fat bubkis.

242.72.text:
We can’t even necessarily presume that they’re
made out of steel.

246.02.text:
For all we know it’s an ultralight, super-durable
ceramic or plastic polymer future nonsense.

255.54.text:
There’s actually something else we can look
at instead of D.va or Bastion.

258.40.text:
Something we have numbers for, and something
that is truly, TRULY massive: Roadhog.

268.56.text:
Sure, from a canonical perspective, there’s
no possible way Roadhog would be able to hook

274.91.text:
another Roadhog, minus some sort of backdoor
cloning facility nonsense nobody told me about.

279.40.text:
But mechanically, this is something Roadhog
is totally capable of.

282.99.text:
Now, about a month ago, I foolishly said that
Roadhog probably weighed about 300-and-some

288.05.text:
pounds, which, at the time seemed to be a
totally reasonable assumption.

291.49.text:
Of course, I didn’t realize that Blizzard
actually tells us exactly how much Roadhog

295.97.text: weighs in one of their cinematics.

303.45.text: Hot damn, that’s a heavy man.

305.22.text:
So first things first: can a 250 kilogram
person actually budge another 250 kilogram

311.17.text:
Because if not, it doesn’t matter what the
heck D.va or Bastion or whatever are made

314.90.text:
out of, because Roadhog will immediately be
complete bullshit.

317.97.text:
And since we have a lot of SCIENCE to do today,
I’m going to spare dangling you on the reveal

323.09.text:
of this one: Roadhog would totally, TOTALLY
be capable of dragging another person of equal

330.36.text:
What we’re essentially looking at is tug-of-war,
except in this case, the target isn’t really

336.34.text:
resisting, since they’re caught off guard,
presumably because they’re stunned by a

340.82.text:
goddam IRON HOOK embedding itself in their
flesh.

343.91.text: The physics of tug-of-war are fucking complicated.

346.62.text: Randall Munroe can back me up on this one.

349.41.text:
There are a lot of forces acting on one another
at different moments, from angular momentum,

356.85.text:
Tug-of-war is rarely won by raw power or weight
anyway.

361.38.text:
Believe it or not, tug-of-war, not unlike
real war, is won by coordination and psychology.

367.23.text:
Professional tug-of-war teams aren’t just
comprised of folk pulling on the rope.

371.19.text:
They also have members called “drivers”
whose sole job it is to stand on the sides

376.26.text:
and shout commands to their team, using motions
to coordinate their pulling, gives commands

380.80.text:
to hang, which means to dig your heels in
and pull back as far as you can go, increasing

385.52.text:
your angle of resistance up until you’re
almost flat against the ground.

389.10.text:
This makes a team almost impossible to budge,
and is designed to tire out the entire team.

394.29.text:
If and when the opposition is worn out, a
good driver gets his team to go gung ho and

399.48.text: tear the other team up off the ground.

401.88.text:
At the end of the day, tug-of-war is a game
of skill, as much as it may seem otherwise.

406.73.text:
Since Roadhog is unlikely to meet any resistance
from a fellow Roadhog, he can totally move

411.82.text:
But this is only half, maybe even a third
of the equation.

414.17.text: Lets get deeper into this topic.

417.89.text: Just, all the way in there.

421.69.text:
Lets look at this hook chain of Roadhog’s
first.

423.68.text:
This bad boy has a range of 20 fucking meters,
and when first thrown, it covers that distance

428.91.text:
in under half a second at a blistering speed
of 63 meters-per-second.

434.03.text:
That’s as fast as the world’s fastest
rollercoaster, the Formula Rossa.

437.42.text:
After 
covering this distance, it hooks the target,

444.54.text:
After 
covering this distance, it hooks the target,

447.08.text: and Roadhog yanks it back to himself.

449.11.text:
It returns somewhat slower, unsurprisingly,
reaching only 40-meters-per-second in just

456.19.text:
That’s more or less how fast you’d be
going if you jumped out of an airplane without

461.20.text:
Before y’all try to point out that Roadhog
appears to have some sort of winch on his

464.46.text:
back like that’s doing all the work for
him, let me just stop you right there.

467.93.text:
Imma let you finnish, but regardless of whether
or not Roadhog’s muscles or the winch is

472.04.text:
doing the pulling, he’s still going to need
to be strong enough to counteract the force

475.90.text:
of the winch, or else what would happen instead
of his enemy getting pulled toward him, Roadhog

480.16.text:
and his enemy would both get dragged across
the ground and crash into one another in the

485.37.text: So just stop it with that nonsense.

487.16.text:
Pulling 250 kilograms of manmeat across 20
meters is no easy feat, let alone doing so

495.32.text:
Before we can even look at whether or not
a person would be strong enough to do this,

499.23.text:
we have to figure out: could a chain even
withstand these kinds of forces?

505.29.text:
Chains are surprisingly easy to break, believe
it or not.

507.75.text:
That’s why you tend to see more cables used
in places where rugged durability is an absolute

513.57.text:
The amount of steel of the same quality formed
into a continuous rope is way, way less likely

521.50.text:
Well, the simple, tl;dr answer is because,
with a chain, all of the force is focused

525.80.text:
on a much smaller area, where the links connect
to one another, whereas with a cable tension

530.56.text:
is much more evenly spread out, and isn’t
focused on specific, small points.

535.25.text: But, alas, Roadhog has a chain.

538.20.text: But ah, not all chains are created equal.

541.62.text:
Chains are manufactured with different grades,
with different tensile strengths.

545.51.text:
Higher grades are of course more expensive,
but if you’re a badass who definitely wants

550.13.text:
to do their hard work with a chain instead
of cable for sheer intimidation factor, price

557.98.text:
Tensile strength is the amount of resistance
a material has to tension, which is pulling

563.38.text:
This is opposed to impact strength, which
is its resistance to getting hit with this,

566.50.text:
shear strength, and compressive strength,
and probably a thousand different others.

573.23.text: Anyway, we just need the one, tensile strength.

575.93.text:
Tension is spread out evenly throughout a
material.

578.44.text: Well, in a perfect world it is, anyway.

580.28.text:
For our purposes, it doesn’t matter that
much.

582.70.text:
We need to figure out exactly how much force
is getting exerted on this chain.

587.00.text:
And in order to do that, we need to do some
basic-ass physics.

590.13.text:
A 250 kilogram roadhog moves from Point A
to Point B, accelerating from 0 meters-per-second

596.50.text:
How fast is Roadhog’s average acceleration,
and how many Newtons of force does a chain

599.80.text: pulling him from Point A to Point B experience?

601.71.text: Be sure to show your work.

611.47.text: This is actually really, really simple.

612.82.text: Force in Newtons is simply mass time acceleration.

616.02.text: Acceleration is velocity divided by time.

617.85.text:
Doing this gives us an acceleration of 80
meters-per-second-squared, which gives us

621.06.text:
a nice, clean force of 20,000 Newtons, or
20 kilonewtons.

626.30.text:
So we just need to find a chain that can withstand
20 kilonewtons of force and then we--AHAH!

633.55.text: This isn’t your High School physics class!

635.58.text:
This is, like, your community college physics
class!

638.33.text: You know what else has mass?

641.04.text:
We absolutely can’t forget to factor in
the weight of any chain we pick, since that’s

645.73.text: going to add to the force.

646.94.text:
Now, this can be a bit tricky, as different
grades of chain at different sizes all have

653.39.text:
And while their masses aren’t negligible,
luckily for us they don’t add THAT Much

658.54.text:
About a thousand Newtons for a Grade 80 chain
that’s 9/32 of an inch thick, which, conveniently,

664.44.text:
has a tensile breaking resistance of over
61 kilonewtons, over three times the tensile

670.58.text: force our chain is going to be experiencing.

676.64.text:
And tossing a chain this heavy would take
a massive 4000 newtons.

680.53.text:
This is a lot, but it’s the kind of forces
bodybuilders experience during a competition,

684.64.text: so it’s within the realm of feasibility.

686.78.text:
Of course this leads us to our next big, big
problem.

697.79.text:
The instant Roadhog yanks that chain back,
over 21 thousand newtons are going to surge

703.52.text:
through that chain, dragging the person on
the other end over to him.

706.78.text:
While the chain does seem as though it will
probably hold together without a problem,

710.67.text:
can a human being even exert this kind of
force on something?

714.17.text:
Enter Louis Cyr, the strongest fucking man
in recorded history.

724.86.text: This dude was a motherfucking badass.

727.17.text:
You know, when I looked up “strongest person
in history,” I expected it to be someone

733.43.text:
I figured that, clearly, with all the modern
technological and medical advances, we’d

741.24.text:
The things is, it turns out, being strong
is an old-as-fuck practice among humanity.

746.86.text: You just gotta lift heavy shit.

750.78.text: And just keep doing that until you die.

753.24.text:
Nowadays strongness isn’t really a valuable
survival attribute, at least not in Western

758.98.text:
Hell, even the military, who are professional
killers, aren’t a strength-based organization.

759.98.text:
Sure, it’s important to be strong, but a
firearm is what does the killing, not, you

760.98.text: know, ripping someone into two pieces.

761.98.text:
And few in history were ever as good at being

763.83.text:
Born in the fucking 19th century, in CANADA
no less, this dude is a certified badass.

770.73.text:
A lot of his feats were totally overblown,
but solid, reliable records can verify that

775.72.text:
he definitely lifted over 500 pounds using
just his finger and carried 18 dudes on a

790.88.text:
So if anybody in history could yank a Roadhog

You see, accelerating at 80 meters-per-second

805.59.text:
over 8 Gs and feel as though it weighed over

814.82.text: over Cyr’s recorded limit of strength.

When thrown, it blitzes through the air at

830.69.text:
Weighing over 21 kilograms, this is like getting

840.28.text:

Of course, we have already established in

850.24.text:

I’m guessing it’s not all that weird at

And, honestly, with the forces and weights
